org.rocketproplab.marginalstability.flightcomputer.hal

Class LSM9DS1

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.rocketproplab.marginalstability.flightcomputer.hal.LSM9DS1
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IMU, PollingSensor

    public class LSM9DS1
extends java.lang.Object
implements PollingSensor, IMU
    The HAL implementation for the LSM9DS1, datasheet can be found here: https://www.st.com/resource/en/datasheet/lsm9ds1.pdf
    Every time poll is called this sensor will acquire as many samples as possible from the LSM9DS1's internal FIFO buffer. This is done by reading the number of samples in the FIFO and then reading the FIFO output registers repeatedly.
    Each sample read gets put into a queue which can be accessed with the getNext() method. Whether or not the queue is empty can be read using the hasNext() method. It is recommended to call hasNext() before each call of getNext().
    Author:
    Max Apodaca

      • mask

        private int mask(int toMask,
                 int newData,
                 int lsbPos,
                 int valueMask)
        Masks the value in toMask with the given parameters. newData is the data to replace the masked bits. LSBPos is how many bits to the left newData is in toMask. valueMask is the mask for the value in newData. valueMask should be right aligned. valueMask will be shifted lsbPos bits to the left before anding with toMask.

        Note: No values in newData are masked out.
        Parameters:
        toMask - the value to mask
        newData - the value to replace the masked areas of to mask
        lsbPos - how far to the left the masked value is in toMask
        valueMask - the mask to apply to toMask but right aligned.
        Returns:
        combination of toMask and newData combined based on valueMask

      • poll

        public void poll()
        Description copied from interface: PollingSensor
        Polls the sensor
        Specified by:
        poll in interface PollingSensor

      • readFromSensor

        private void readFromSensor()
        Read as many samples as possible from the sensor. This method will read the number of samples in the FIFO by calling getSamplesInFIFO() and then read that many samples. The read is done by reading register OUT_X_L_G which will automatically advance until the sample is read. This means we will read BYTES_PER_FIFO_LINE (12) * N bytes where N is the number of samples in the FIFO.

        If this method is ever extended make sure to read less than 8000 bytes at a time as that is the limit of the I2C driver. We will read at most 372 bytes as the maximum FIFO size is 31 samples.

      • parseReadings

        private void parseReadings(byte[] data,
                           int bytesRead)
        Take the raw data read and split it into chunks of BYTES_PER_FIFO_LINE bytes to correspond to each IMU reading. Then feed those into buildReading(byte[]).
        Parameters:
        data - the raw data to parse
        bytesRead - how many bytes were read.

      • buildReading

        public IMUReading buildReading(byte[] data)
        Parse a set of BYTES_PER_FIFO_LINE bytes into an IMUReading.
        TODO Use range to normalize to m/s^2
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the IMUReading which the six bytes belong to.

      • getData

        private int[] getData(byte[] data)
        Converts the input bytes to shorts where it assumes that the first byte of the tuple is less significant.
        The array looks like [L,H,L,H, ..., L, H].
        Parameters:
        data - byte array of little-endian shorts
        Returns:
        array of the shorts

        Returns:
